Jane T. is from the village of San Antonio, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 55 years old. Jane is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Jane owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing tailoring business to local community members. Jane has been engaged in her business for over 38 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Jane is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Jane from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita R. is from the village of San Antonio, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 53 years old. Merlita is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Merlita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. In future he expects his business to grow into a big retail shop. He wants the loan to enable him to buy cooking oil, soap, sugar, rice and other domestic items to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 50-year-old widow with three children aged 27, 22, and 6 years old. She has three dependents and lives in her own house. Her family goal is to have wealthy and educated children. Her address is Masindi, Uganda.

She has a retail shop and has been in the business for nine years. She started with only a little capital which has now grown but says she faces a challenge of high electricity and water bills.  She intends to use the loan to purchase sugar, soap, cooking oil, bread, rice for reselling in her shop.

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, soap, cooking oil, bread, rice for resale

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 36-year-old man, married with three children aged 6 years, 2 years and 7 months. He has no other dependents and lives in a 4-roomed house which he owns. His family goal is to have a healthy and well educated family. His home address is Masindi, Uganda.

He is in the retail business and farming and has been in the businesses for 2 and 10 years respectively. He started with farming just like the majority of the country's population. He put aside savings from his income and started the retail business. He faces hardships of bad debts and he wishes in future that his business will grow into a big retail shop. He needs the loan to pay school fees for his child.

loans.use: Paying school fees for his child

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing wedding and gown rental services to local community members. Edwardo has been engaged in his business for more than 35 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Edwardo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a 31-year-old woman, married with four children aged 12, 8, 6, and 1. She cares for her family and lives in her own permanent house. Her family goal is to educate her children. Her home address is Masindi, Uganda. 

She is into the poultry business and has been doing it for two years now. She started with a few chicks but now has many and the challenge she faces is that chicken feed is expensive. In future she wishes to expand her business to supply both broilers and layers. She needs the loan to buy more chicks.

loans.use: Buy more chicks for her poultry business

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
Salim is a 41-year-old man, married with four children aged 14,10, 5 and 2 years old. He has no other dependents and lives with a family of six members. He owns his home and his family goal is to have well educated children. He lives in Masindi, Uganda.

He is into  the motorcycle transport business and has been doing it for 4 years. He bought a motorcycle using his salary and faces a challenge of motorcycle break down, given the terrain of his business area. In future he sees his business having more motorcycles and himself having a private school. He wants the loan to enable him to buy spare parts for his motorcycle and pay repair costs so that he can continue operating his transport business.

loans.use: Buying spare parts for his motorcycle and paying repair costs

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 38 years old, married with 5 children aged 19, 17, 10, 14, and 8 years old. She has 2 other dependents and lives with a family of 7 members. She owns her home and her family goal is to have a wealthy family. She lives in Masindi, Uganda.

She is into the produce business, selling millet. Her business has been running for seven years now. She started by selling local brew and now has a stock of about 5,000,000UGX. She faces a challenge of transporting the millet from the farmers and of limited capital. In future she expects her business to be in a bigger produce store than today. She wants the loan to enable her to buy more millet to sell at a margin.

loans.use: Buying more millet to sell at a margin

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred is a 54-year-old married man with 6 children and has 4 other dependents. He lives in his own residential house with 4 family members. His family goal is to have educated children and a farm. His home address is Masindi, Uganda. 

He is into the transportation business and has been running it for one year. He bought the vehicle using his retirement package. He faces a challenge of high fuel prices and obtaining vehicle spare parts. In future he wishes to have a fleet of trucks and he wants the loan to purchase new tyres for his vehicle.

loans.use: Buying tyres for his vehicle for transport business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Paying labor for clearing his farm land for cultivation

loans.name: Rutaraka Twimukye Group

texts.en: Emmanuel, a 41-year-old living in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda is a father to six children and owns a maize-milling machine that he has operated for 5 years. He dreams of having several machines in different areas to capture a bigger market in future. He wants a loan to buy spare parts for the milling machine.

loans.use: Buying spare parts for maize-milling machine

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is a 33-year-old man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is a father to two children aged 11 and 1. He owns a residential house where he lives. He is into the motorcycle business and has been in it for nine years now. He says he has managed to buy land and also construct a semi-permanent house through his business gains.

 William says it is tough for his business during the rainy seasons  as customers are hard to come by because of the rain and that competition has increased in his business sector of motorcycle transport. He intends to use the loan to buy a motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.use: Buying a motorcycle for transport business

loans.name: Archangel

texts.en:
Archangel is a 50-year-old man, married to a wife who is a farmer with whom he has six children, living in a semi permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Just like his wife, Archangel is a farmer and has been farming for the last 10 years. Having been a subsistence farmer at the start, Archangel is now a commercial farmer but adds that farming is unpredictable due to weather changes which sometimes are not expected. 

His desire is to have all his children well educated but for now, he doesn’t have enough money for school fees thus needs a loan. Archangel intends to use the loan funds to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Paying school fees for the children

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
He is a 41-year-old farmer. He is married with five children aged 17, 15, 13, 8 and 3 years and is named Alfred. Alfred lives in Fort Portal, Uganda in his own house but dreams of having a commercial building for rentals one day and of buying more land for his family. 

Alfred’s wife is also a farmer and together they have a plantation and also rear goats to sell after maturity. He says theft and price fluctuations are his biggest threats in his business activities. This is Alfred’s first loan from HOFOKAM and he intends to use the funds to buy fertilizers for his plantation and one Boer goat to rear.

loans.use: Buying fertilizers for his plantation and one goat to rear

loans.name: Claire

texts.en:
Claire is a 35-year-old lady, single mother of one child aged eight years. She lives in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is into selling used shoes, a business she has now operated for five years. 

Having started with very little capital, Claire has seen her business grow over the years and she hopes it continues along that line though she adds that sales are sometimes uncertain depending on the season. Claire wants this loan to enable her to purchase more used shoes to sell at her stall.

loans.use: Purchasing second-hand shoes for resale

loans.name: Yasin

texts.en:
He is young, ambitious and hard-working. He is 23 years old, married with two children, aged 3 and 2 years. His name is Yasin. He lives in Fort Portal, Uganda where he operates a used shoe business having started it four years ago. He says it has been good so far as he has been able to buy a plot of land from his business gains and some cattle. He adds that bad debts and seasonality are the challenges he has to deal with as he strives to earn a living from selling used shoes. He hopes to see his business bigger in size in the future. 

Yasin intends to use the loan to purchase more used shoes to sell and one heifer for his farm.

loans.use: Purchase more used shoes for resale and one heifer for his farm.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase important materials for his shop

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba F. is married. She smokes fish for sale at Elmina. Her husband is a mechanic.  Aba uses her income to help her husband to take care of the home.  Aba will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to smoke for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba anticipates reinvesting her increased profit back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more fresh fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Stella Efua

texts.en: Stella Efua E. A. is married. She has been through junior high school. Stella E. sells underwear at Elmina. Her husband is a fisherman. Stella feeds her family as a way of helping her husband. She wishes to purchase more of her goods for sale with the help of the loan. With the new profits from her expanded business, Stella hopes to save toward building a house.

loans.use: purchase more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Rebecca Ekua Mana

texts.en:
Rebecca Ekua Mana M. sells 'kenkey' (fermented maize dough) at Elmina. She is married and has no educational background.  Her husband is a carpenter.  

Rebecca uses her income to help her husband to take care of the home.  She will use the loan to purchase more maize to prepare 'kenkey' for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Rebecca plans to save to build a house.

loans.use: purchase more maize to prepare 'kenkey' for sale

loans.name: Cecelia Nyame Na

texts.en: Cecelia Nyame Na O. Q. is married and has six dependents. She has no educational background.  Cecelia sells rice and beans at Elmina. Her husband is a farmer.  Cecelia uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Cecelia will use the loan to purchase more rice and beans for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Cecelia plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: purchase more rice and beans for sale

loans.name: Grace Adwoa Kubruku

texts.en: Grace Adwoa Kubruku A. sells fruit at Elmina. She is married to a farmer. Grace has been selling fruit for seven years. She responsibly helps her husband in taking care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy extra fruit for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: buy extra fruit for sale

loans.name: Elizabeth Nana Ama

texts.en: Elizabeth Nana Ama A. K. operates a food joint at Elmina. Elizabeth has no educational background.  She is married and been in this food business for five years. She helps her husband in providing the basic needs of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs to cook for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to put up a better place where she can sell.

loans.use: buy more foodstuffs to cook for sale

loans.name: Elizabeth Ekua Kwesiwa

texts.en: Elizabeth Ekua Kwesiwa K. is married and has five dependents. She has no educational background.  Elizabeth Ekua Kwesiwa sells bedsheets, cosmetics and dresses at Elmina. Her husband is a farmer. Elizabeth uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Elizabeth will use the loan she hopes to get to purchase more clothing for resale. With the new revenue from her expanded business, Elizabeth wishes to save to build a shop.

loans.use: purchase more clothing for resale

loans.name: Comfort Aba

texts.en: Comfort Aba K. A. is married. She sells locally-made buicuits at Elmina. She has junior high educational background. Her husband is a farmer. Comfort uses the income she makes from her sales to help in providing the basic needs of the family.  Comfort will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to prepare her biscuits for sale. With the new revenue from her expanded business, Comfort plans on reinvesting into her business.

loans.use: purchase more ingredients to use to prepare her biscuits for sale

loans.name: Georgina Nana Keti

texts.en: Georgina Nana Keti A. sells children's wear and cosmetics at Elmina by moving from one area to another. Georgina has not been educated. She is a single parent taking care of her child. She responsibly takes care of the family with the sales she makes from her business. Her loan will be used to buy extra goods for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards her child’s education.

loans.use: buy extra goods for sale

loans.name: Veronica Ekua Egyeiwa

texts.en: Veronica Ekua Egyeiwa O. sells hair creams and other hair products at Elmina. Ekua has junior high educational background. She is married to a farmer. She helps her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more creams and other hair products for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to expand her business.

loans.use: buy more creams and other hair products for sale

loans.name: Mary Mena

texts.en: Mary Mena A. is married to a driver and together they live with their two children. She has senior high educational background. Mena sells provisions at Elmina. Mena uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Mena will use the loan to purchase additional provisions for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mena plans to save to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: purchase additional provisions for sale

loans.name: Cecelia Aba

texts.en: Cecelia Aba A. sells 'kenkey' and maize at Elmina.  Cecelia Aba has no educational background. Her husband is a farmer. Cecelia has been selling 'kenkey' for two years. She helps her husband to take care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more maize to prepare 'kenkey' for sale. She hopes to reinvest the new profit back into her business.

loans.use: buy more maize to prepare' kenkey' (fermented maize dough) for sale

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati G. is married and has five dependents. She is married to a driver and has no educational background. Fati is into the sale of cassava, onions, plantain and cocoyams at Abura. She has been in this business for eighteen years now. She will use the loan to purchase more of her foodstuffs for sale. She hopes to use the new profit from her business to purchase a piece of land.

loans.use: purchase more of her foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Hajaratu

texts.en: Hajaratu I. is a palm oil extractor at Abura. She has received junior high education. Hajaratu is married to a farmer and has eight dependents. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to purchase more palm fruits to process oil to meet the demand of her customers. She hopes to use the new profit to educate her dependents.

loans.use: purchase more palm fruits to process into oil

loans.name: Volodymyr

texts.en:
Volodymyr is married with two teenage children. He is a businessman from Skvira. Volodymyr raises poultry, i.e. chickens, geese, ducks and turkeys, and sells them in the local grocery market. 

He used to have an old car that he used to transport poultry to the market. Recently Volodymyr managed to purchase a van for that specific purpose. It is more spacious, which allows Volodymyr to bring and sell more poultry every time. Volodymyr has been in the market for eight years. He has already invested more than 80,000 Grivnyas in his venture. His monthly net profit is usually less than 10,000 Grivnyas.  

Volodymyr is requesting a loan of 21,000 Grivnyas to construct a chicken coop and repair the engine of his van that he uses for poultry transportation. Volodymyr is planning to construct a chicken coop as it is much cheaper to have one than to rent one. Rent would cost him another 2,000 Grivnyas in expenses every month. Volodymyr’s wife is actively helping him run the business.

loans.use: to construct a chicken coop and repair the engine of his van

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena A. has senior high educational background. She is married and lives together with her five dependents. She sells provisions at Abura. Her husband is a farmer. 

Abena will use the loan to buy more provisions to sell. She responsibly helps her husband in providing the basic need of her family. She plans on using the new increase from her business to save towards her children’s education.

loans.use: buy more provisions to sell

loans.name: Hajara

texts.en: Hajara T. sells soap and is a seamstress at Abura. She is married and lives with her husband who is an electrician. She has been though junior high school. She supports her husband by feeding the home. The loan will be used to purchase more cloth to sew for sale. She anticipates reinvesting her profit back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more cloth to sew for sale

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena A. has no educational background. She is divorced and takes care of four children. She sells provisions and roasted plantains at Abura. She has been roasting plantains for sale for some time now. She takes care of her family with the income she makes from her sales. She will use the loan to purchase more plantains to roast for sale.

loans.use: purchase more plantains to roast for sale

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en: Fatima W. is married and takes care of six dependents. She sells cassava and maize at Abura. She is married to a security man. She has been in this trade for twenty years. She has no educational background.  She helps her husband in the general welfare of her home. She will use the loan to buy more maize and cassava for sale.

loans.use: buy more maize and cassava for sale

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is divorced. She is a market entrepreneur from Berdyansk. Ludmila sells shoes, sandals, flip flops and other footwear items. Ludmila started her business four years ago. Presently, her turnover capital is about 18,000 Grivnyas. Her income is less than 10,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Ludmila understands the value of customer service – a quality which sets her apart from many other business owners. She is attentive and polite to her customers and tries to give them each her individual attention, which is why she has many loyal customers. Ludmila has requested a loan of 3,500 Grivnyas to increase her working capital. She is planning to purchase additional merchandise and sell it at a reasonable price.

loans.use: to increase her working capital

loans.name: Mujeres Sin Fronteras Group

texts.es:
La alcancía comunal “MUJERES SIN FRONTERAS”, se encuentra ubicada en la San Juana Bautista 3ª Etapa en el distrito de Comas, departamento de Lima, está conformado por 8 socios quienes se desempeñan en labores de comercio minorista, trabajan con EDAPROSPO- Prosperidad desde hace 8 meses.
Sara Delfina emprendedora y entusiasta, tiene 50 años,  es madre soltera, ya que su conviviente falleció hace 10 años y tiene 4 hijos, de los cuales 2 de ellos viven con ella.
Desde hace 6 meses se dedica a la venta de comida en un puesto de mercado (menú criollo), el cual lleva por nombre “SARITA”, se inicio en este negocio ya que anteriormente, durante muchos años se desempeño como cocinera en una clínica, con el esfuerzo de su trabajo y a base de mucho esfuerzo ha logrado construir su vivienda y acaba de techarlo, pero aun le falta el acabado final, con el ingreso de su negocio cubre los gastos de alimentos, pago de servicios, educación, etc. 
El gran anhelo de Sara es tener su propio restaurante en su vivienda y contratar personal para así generar empleo para los demás.
Con el reciente préstamo adquirido los socios de la alcancía, lo utilizaran en la compra de mercadería y otros artículos  para cubrir la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
The “MUJERES SIN FRONTERAS” (Women Without Borders) communal bank is located in the third stage of San Juana Bautista, in the Comas district, within the Lima department.  It’s made up of eight members who run small businesses and who’ve been working with EDAPROSPO-Prosperidad for the past eight months.

Sara Delfina is an enthusiastic entrepreneur.  She is a 50 year old single mother whose husband passed away ten years ago.  She has four children, two of whom live with her.

She’s been selling food (Creole style) from a stall in the market for six months.  Her business is called “SARITA” and she started it after having worked as a cook in a clinic for many years.  With the effort she puts into her work, and also much more effort, she’s managed to build her house and has recently installed a roof, but it still needs some final touches.  She uses the income from her work to pay for food, services, education, etc.

Sara’s greatest desire is to have her own restaurant in her home and to hire people so that she can provide work for others.

The communal bank members will use the money from this loan to buy merchandise and other items to cover their customer demand.

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Primavera Group

texts.es:
Augusto asume el cargo D. presidente,D. la alcancia comunal “PRIMAVERA” conformada por  13 socios entusiastas y emprendedores, quienes realizan diversas actividades como: producción,  comercio y servicio, ellos vienen trabajando con EDAPROSPO- Prosperidad desD. hace 5 años.
Augusto tiene 53 años, casado, y tiene 2 hijos. DesD. hace 20 años se dedica a la venta D. pescado en el terminal pesquero, se inicio en este negocio porque inicialmente era ayudante D. una persona que vendía pescado, luego decidió independizarse, con el esfuerzo D. su trabajo ha logrado la construcción D. su vivienda, con el ingreso D. su negocio cubre los gastos D. alimentos y pago D. servicios, nos cuenta que su gran meta es ampliar mas su negocio.
El reciente préstamo será destinado a la compra D. mercadería, todos nuestros socios agradecen el apoyo brindado y se comprometen a pagar en los plazos pactados.
texts.en:
The “Primavera” (Springtime) Communal Bank is comprised of 13 enthusiastic and enterprising members.  They work at  different activities like production, commerce, and service.  They have been working with EDAPROSPO- Prosperidad for five years.

Augosto is the president.  He is 53 years old, married, and has two children.  He has been selling fish at the fishing terminal for 20 years.  He started this business because he used to be a helper to a person who sold fish, and Agosto decided to become independent.  Through his work efforts he has managed to build his house.  The income from his business covers the food expenses and pays for services.  He tells us that his big goal is to expand his business more.

The loan he is requesting is to buy merchandise.

All of the members are grateful for the support, and they pledge to make their payments on time.

loans.use: compra de mercadería

loans.name: Los Emprendedores De Las Lomas Group

texts.es:
La alcancía comunal “LOS EMPRENDEDORES D. LAS LOMAS”, está conformada por 9 socios entusiastas y luchadores quienes tienen por afinidad dedicarse al comercio minorista, trabajan con EDAPROSPO – prosperidad desD. hace 9 años.
Martha es una socia del grupo y a su vez asume el cargo D. tesorera desD. hace 4 meses, tiene 57 años, es casada, tiene 4 hijos, D. los cuales tres viven con ella. Martha actualmente tiene un Colegio Educativo llamado Alfonso Sagardia  Marillas desD. hace 8 años en su domicilio, se inicio en este negocio porque quería dar una mejor calidad educativa a los niños, nos cuenta que empezó con solo 12 niños en una cas D. madera. Con el esfuerzo D. su labor ha logrado mejorar la educación y la infraestructura del colegio, y su calidad D. vida. 
El reciente préstamo será utilizado para mejorar la infraestructura del colegio, nuestros socios se sienten muy agradecidos por el apoyo recibido y se comprometen en la puntualidad D. sus pagos.
texts.en:
The “LOS EMPRENDEDORES D. LAS LOMAS” (The Las Lomas Entrepreneurs) communal bank has 9 enthusiastic, hard working members who are retailers for the most part.  They have collaborated with EDAPROSPO-Prosperidad for the last 9 years.

Martha is a group member who also has taken on the function of Treasurer for the last four months.  She is 57 years old, married and has four children three of whom still live with her.

Martha has had a school called, Alfonso Sagardia Marillas, in her home for the last 8 years.  She started this business because she wanted to proviD. a better quality education to children.  She tells us that she started out with just 12 students in a wooden house.  With her work’s labor she has managed to improve education, the school’s infrastructure and her quality of life.

The current loan will be used to improve the school’s infrastructure.

Our members are very grateful for the support received and commit to pay their installments on time.

loans.use: To improve the school's infrastructure.

loans.name: Jacob Wanambisi

texts.en:
Jacob Wanambisi W. is a 69-year-old man who is married to Doreen Wanambisi. They have ten children between 10 and 28 years old. They live in Maili Saba Kitale-Kenya. He sells firewood and charcoal. He has been in this business for the past eight years and he is now able make a monthly profit of KES 16000. 

Jacob is applying for his fourth loan with KADET of KES 35000, and he intends to buy more firewood and 10 bags of charcoal. With the profit, he wants to get into the brick-making business. He will supply bricks to people who are building and developing plots.

Jacob also hopes to develop the plots he owns and build rental homes. He believes this will provide enough money to enable him to take all of his children to better schools that provide a better education.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Phyllis Njeri

texts.en:
Phyllis Njeri K. is 32 years old and married to James Macharia, who is also a businessman. They have three children, ages 12, 10 and 5 years. Phyllis sells firewood and she has been in this business for the past six years. From her business, she gets a monthly profit of KES 8000.

She is applying for her first loan with KADET of KES 20000, and she intends to buy more firewood. With the profit, she wants to open a new business selling cereals. 

Phyllis hopes that in the future her children will have a better education.

loans.use: To buy more firewood

loans.name: El Cruce Hacia El Futuro (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal El Cruce hacia el Futuro está formado por 9 mujeres de una misma comunidad como es el Cruce que pertenece a la parroquia de Sinincay,  su gente se dedica a la cría de animales y a la agricultura la misma que es para su consumo, también salen a la ciudad en busca de un buen empleo. Nuestras socias son mujeres luchadoras quienes día a día buscan un mejor bienestar para sus familias y con su trabajo mejoran la economía de sus hogares, son mujeres muy alegres y lo demuestran en cada reunión de la banca comunal.

La Señora. Jhoanna J. vive por el sector de las Malvinas en la ciudad de Cuenca. Tiene 19 años, es casada hace poco tiempo y por el momento no tiene hijos, su esposo es carpintero, no tienen casa propia por lo que  viven arrendando. 
La Señora. Jhoanna trabaja administrando su propio taller de carpintería en el que labora hace un año, trabaja en las tardes ya que en la mañana se dedica al arreglo de su hogar. Se encuentra en su tercer ciclo y todos los créditos le han beneficiado para la compra de materiales y ahora con este nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de madrea y tintes para su carpintería.
 
Su meta es  llegar a tener su casa propia.

La Señora María C. vive en la comunidad de El Cruce que  pertenece a la parroquia de Sinincay. Tiene 46 años, es casada y  tiene 4 hijo de 28, 24, 14 y 12 años de edad, su primer hijo se dedica a trabajar y ayuda en la economía del hogar, su segundo hijo es casado y vive  independientemente  y sus dos últimas hijas  estudian en un colegio de la ciudad, su esposo es de profesión escultor,  trabaja en mármol y tiene  un taller propio en casa, la casa en la que habitan es propia.
Doña María es socia de la banca comunal hace 5 años y tiene una gran amistad con todas las socias de la banca comunal, es un grupo de mujeres unidas con un solo fin, que es seguir creciendo en sus negocios. Nuestra socia hace 3 años se dedica a la cría de cuyes y pollos, los vende pelados en su comunidad. El nuevo crédito que realiza en la banca comunal lo va a invertir en la compra de alimento para sus animales.
  
Su meta es  seguir creciendo en su negocio.
texts.en:
The “El Cruce hacia el Futuro” (Crossroad to the Future) communal bank is composed of 9 women from the same, El Cruce, community which is part of Sinincay parish.  Its residents raise farm animals and grow crops for their own consumption; they also go to the city looking for a good job.  Our members are hard working women who seek daily to improve their families’ wellbeing and to improve their home’s income through their hard work. They are women who are cheerful and who exhibit this at each communal bank meeting.

Mrs. Jhoanna J. lives around the Malvinas area of Cuenca.  She is 19 years old, married a short time ago, and with no children for the time being.  Her husband is a carpenter.  They do not own their own home.  They rent.  

Jhoanna runs her own carpentry shop where she has been working for a year.  She works in the afternoon because during the morning she tends to her home. 

This is her third loan cycle and all previous loans have been used to buy materials.  The new loan will be used to buy wood and wood stains for her carpentry.

Her goal is to have a house of her own.

Mrs. María C. lives in El Cruce which is part of Sinincay parish.  She is 46 years old, married and has four children who are 28, 24, 14 and 12 years of age.  Her oldest son is employed and helps with household expenses.  Her second son is married and lives independently.  Her youngest two daughters are in school in the city.  Her husband is a sculptor.  He works in marble and has a shop installed in their home.  They own their house.

María has been a member of the communal bank for 5 years.  She is a good friend of all the other members.  It is a group of women united with a single goal: to continue growing in their businesses.

Our member has raised guinea pigs and chickens for three years.  She sells them already dressed in her community. 

She will use the new loan she’s getting in the communal bank to buy feed for her animals.

Her goal is to continue growing in her business.

loans.use: To buy wood and wood stains and to buy animal feed.

loans.name: Felix Pedro

texts.es: Félix Pedro Q. C. tiene 32 años de edad, es casado y padre de tres hijos de 15, 11, y 3 años, se dedica a las estructuras metálicas y reside en el Barrio Nuevo Paraíso del municipio de Santa María del Real, Catacamas, Olancho. Félix inició su trayecto como microempresario hace 15 años con la instalación de una pulpería en su casa de habitación y actualmente también tiene un taller de estructuras metálicas que atiende de 7:00 am a 4:00 pm, y su esposa le ayuda a atender la pulpería y los quehaceres del hogar. Félix se siente muy agradecido con Dios porque le ha dado la sabiduría necesaria para administrar muy bien sus negocios y con eso ha podido cubrir los gastos familiares y escolares de sus dos hijos mayores. Una de las dificultades del negocio es que en ciertas temporadas los trabajos a realizar son muy pocos pero la ventaja es que también cuenta con su pulpería y eso le ayuda a sostener a su familia. Los problemas que actualmente enfrenta son el deterioro de sus herramientas de trabajo y que su hijo de 15 años tuvo un accidente y eso le está ocasionando gastos médicos. Él solicita el financiamiento para ampliar una parte de su taller y necesita comprar materiales de construcción como cemento, varilla, bloques, arena, etc. y así mejorar la presentación de su negocio y atraer más clientes. Su sueño es que su negocio crezca cada día para así darle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en: Félix Pedro Q. C. is 32-years-old.  He is married and is the father of three children who are 15, 11, and 3-years-old.  He works in metal structures and lives in the Nuevo Paraíso [New Paradise] neighborhood in the town of Santa María del Real, Catacamas, Olancho.  Félix began his journey as a small businessman 15 years ago when he put a small grocery store in his home, and now he also has a workshop for metal structures that he opens from 7:00 am to 4:00 pm while his wife helps him with the grocery store and the household chores.  Félix feels very grateful to God because He has given him the wisdom needed to administer his businesses well and with this he has been able to cover the family expenses and school fees for his two oldest children.  One of the difficulties of his business is that there are times when there is little work to do, but the advantage is that he also has the grocery store and this helps him to support his family.  The problems he is facing right now are the deterioration of his work tools and that his 15-year-old son had and accident and this is incurring medical bills.  He is requesting the loan to expand a part of his workshop and for this he needs to buy construction materials like cement, rebar, blocks, sand, etc. With this he will be able to improve the appearance of his business and attract more customers.  His dream is that his business will grow each day so that he can give his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: Purchase Construction Materials

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
This is Josephine A., 49, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Ricardo A., a salesman. She is the mother of three children, all of whom are living at home and helping her manage the household and the business. By the grace of God, Josephine has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college, a dream for most Filipino parents like Josephine. She herself has been a college undergraduate, and she believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Josephine maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. Josephine buys her customers' orders in cash and then gives them to the customers. The customers have one month to pay her. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits. Josephine's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 16000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Josephine dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet weekly. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for her customers' orders

loans.name: Jagir

texts.en:
Jagir D. is 55 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Hovd Province, Mongolia. Jagar operates a clothing stand at the market with the help of his wife and children. He started his business in 2000 repairing shoes, and after years of successful operation and experience broadened his business activities and started another clothing booth at the Ih Buyan market in 2009.

He says, "My wife and I have worked hard to pay tuition fees for our three children, and now they have all graduated from their universities. Now we need to help them have their own lives separate from us.” He is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothing for help expand his retail trade business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Mujeres Soñadoras (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres Soñadoras está formado por 9 mujeres que viven en diferentes partes de la ciudad de Cuenca,  esta es la tercera ciudad  más importante del Ecuador. su gente mantiene su cultura y tradiciones,  es muy amable y cordial al igual que nuestras socias, quienes son mujeres trabajadoras que están en la lucha para lograr sus objetivos que es mejorar la economía de sus hogares.

La Señora Ana C. vive por el sector de Medio Ejido en la ciudad de Cuenca, este es  el primer  crédito que realiza en la banca comunal, fue invitada por una amiga.  
Nuestra socia tiene de 24 años,  es casada y tiene 2 hijos de 5 y 1 año de edad, su primer hijo esta estudiando en una escuelita de la ciudad, su esposo es de profesión albañil, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando. 
Doña Ana hace 6 meses se ha dedicado a la venta de cosméticos Yanbal y Avon,  labora todo el tiempo que le sea posible sin descuidar su casa y a su familia.
Su crédito lo va  a invertir en la compra de mas cosméticos como son perfumes, cremas etc.
Su meta es llegar a comprarse un vehiculo.
 
La Señora Ruth vive por el sector de Cristo Rey. Tiene 46 años,  es casada y tiene   3 hijos de 21, 15 y 14 años de edad, su primer hijo trabaja esta estudiando en la universidad, sus dos últimos hijos estudian en un colegio de la ciudad, su esposo es dueño de dos camiones pesados pero por el momento no se encuentra trabajando en su negocio ya que está enfermo y pasa en casa, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando. 
Doña Ruth hace 4 meses se ha puesto una pequeña tienda en la cual labora de domingo a domingo desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche, también sabe elaborar artesanías pero por el momento ha dejado este negocio y se dedica solo a su tienda. Este es el primer crédito que realiza en la banca comunal. Su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de más productos para su tienda como: arroz, azúcar, aceites, etc., y también es para hacer unos pequeños arreglos a su local.

Su meta es compra un almacén de repuestos para que su esposo se dedique a este trabajo y deje su trabajo actual.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Soñadoras communal bank consists of nine women that live in different parts of the city of Cuenca, the third most important city in Ecuador. The people of Cuenca maintain their culture and traditions. They are very friendly and polite, just like the group members, who are hardworking women who are fighting to achieve their goal of improving their household economies.

Ana C. lives in the Medio Ejido area of the city of Cuenca and this is her first loan with the communal bank. She was invited by a friend. Ana is 24 years old and has two children who are 5 and 1. Her first child is studying at a school in the city. Ana’s husband is a builder and they do not have their own house, which is why they are renting.

For the past six months, Ana has been working selling cosmetics from Yanbal and Avon. She works all that she can without neglecting her house and her family. She will invest her loan in the purchase of more cosmetics like perfumes, creams, etc. Her goal in the future is to buy a car.

Ruth lives in the Cristo Rey area. She is 46 years old, married, and has three children who are 21, 15, and 14 years old. Her oldest is a university student and the two others are in high school in the city. Her husband owns two large trucks but he is not currently working at his business because he is sick and at home. They do not have their own house, which is why they are renting.

Four months ago, Ruth set up a small store where she works all week from 6am to 10pm. She also knows how to make handicrafts but has currently left that business and is only working at her store. This is her first loan with the communal bank and she will invest it in the purchase of more products for her store such as rice, sugar, oils, etc. She will also use it to make a few repairs in the place. Her goal is to buy a warehouse for spare parts so that her husband can work in this business and leave his current job.

loans.use: To buy creams, perfumes, costume jewelry and cosmetics - To buy rice, sugar, oil, eggs and general groceries

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en:
Lhagvasuren Z. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent, in Huvsgul Province, Mongolia. His children attend a local school and his wife works as a cook at “Dalai Van”. A very hardworking, open-minded and experienced driver, Lhagvasuren has operated a taxi service business in his town since 2002.

He says, " I hope to save enough money to support my family's needs and improve my car." He is now requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a good car for a safe and fast taxi service.

loans.use: To purchase a good car

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena L., from the village of Angga-an, Damulog, Bukidnon, is 36 years old and married. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 4000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita L., 58, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a widow. Her three children are already working and helping her with the household and the finances. By the grace of God, Teresita has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Teresita operates a variety store where her main products are mostly school supplies. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a few pesos worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She makes money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rates.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an 11,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, beverages, and school supplies to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Teresita dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship[sup]*[/sup]* members to share stories of her work every week.

<sup>*</sup>All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Ana Mae

Ana Mae has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2010, Ana Mae joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Ana Mae is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ana Mae from HSPFI. loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
This is Violeta C., 55, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Florante C., a retired pensioner, and mother of five adults, all of whom are already working and helping her with the household and finances. As of the present time, Violeta is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Violeta maintains a pharmacological direct selling business. She sells DXN, a local brand of herbal medicines and health supplements. Also included in the inventory are vitamins. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are counting on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 1500 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 28,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Violeta has always dreamed of having her house fixed and renovated. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying orders for her customers

loans.name: Sandra Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Sandra del Carmen P., tienen la edad de 41 años, vive en el Barrio El Edén es casada, ellos tienen 3 hijos mayores de edad que trabajan por cuenta propia y sobreviven bajo sus propios medios, ellos son agricultores desde hace 20 años y durante este largo periodo se han enfrentado a las plagas y sequias, y es para sus cultivos que solicita un préstamo para la compra de fertilizantes, fungicidas, e insumos vegetativos, que permitan una mejor cosecha que favorezca a un incremento en las ventas, y a futuro contar con los recursos económicos para remodelar su hogar y dejársela de herencia a sus hijos para el bienestar y provecho de sus futuras familias.
texts.en: Sandra del Carmen Perez, 41, lives in the El Eden neighborhood.  She is married and they have 3 adult children who work on their own and support themselves.  Sandra and her husband have been farmers for 20 years, and over this long period of time they have confronted diseases and droughts.  They request a loan to buy fertilizers, fungicides and farming supplies for their crops.  This will allow them to have a better harvest and increase their sales and, in the future, have the resources to renovate their home and leave an inheritance to their children for the benefit and well-being of their future families.

loans.use: supplies to maintain the health of their crops

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa M. is from the village of Santo Domingo, Echague, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Rosa is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a canteen in the community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $63 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ricardo De Jesús

texts.es: El señor Ricardo de Jesús R. H. tiene la edad de 48 años, habita con su pareja de vida y sus 3 hijos en el Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla, sus dos hijos laboran y generan sus ingresos de manera independiente, el menor es el que depende económicamente del señor,  ellos se dedican desde hace mas de 20 años al cultivo de la piña, a futuro esperan contar con los recursos económicos para la adquisición de un camioneta para el transporte de las cosechas y su venta inmediata, ellos a lo largo de su dedicación en esta actividad, se han enfrentado a problemas de enfermedades de las tierras  provocadas por las plagas, sequias y la disminución en los cultivos por los gases que emana el volcán que se encuentra a las cercanías de sus terrenos, es para su negocio que solicita un préstamo para la implantación de un mantenimiento fitosanitario, el crédito lo ocupara en la comprad e fertilizantes, fungicidas, e insumos vegetativos que permitan una mejor producción y la recuperación de la inversión.
texts.en: Ricardo de Jesús R. H., 48, lives with his life partner and their 3 children in the Juan Ramón Padilla neighborhood.  Two of their children work and generate their own incomes.  The youngest child is still dependent.  For more than 20 years Ricardo and his partner have cultivated pineapples.  In the future, they hope to have sufficient resources to purchase a truck so that they can transport their own harvests and sell their products quickly.  During the time that they have been farming they have faced problems such as plant diseases caused by plagues, droughts and diminished output due to the gases that emanate from the volcano that is located close to their land.  They request a loan for their business to help them maintain healthy crops.  They will use the loan to buy fertilizers, fungicides and other farming supplies that will allow them to increase their production and their return on investment.

loans.use: to buy supplies to maintain healthy crops

To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $127 a month for these activities.

In 2005, Aida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. 

Aida is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 11th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.
