Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase poultry feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina G. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 61 years old. Rosalina is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Rosalina owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling used-clothing & shoe products in the local community. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Rosalina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To solve his family problems.

loans.name: Nansikombi

texts.en: Nansikombi S. began her pub business 12 years ago in Bugembe-Jinja with savings from a rental business. It is a business undertaking which, to say the least, has been worthwhile to her in terms of accrued profits over the years. Her first business was retailing. In a week, her profits add up to shillings 70,000. S. is married and has 4 sparkling kids. With this loan she is anticipating the purchase of more crates of beer, spirits and wines for resale at her pub.

loans.use: The purchase of more crates of beer, spirits and wines for resale at her pub.

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en:
Felipa M. is from the village of Kabatangan, Wao, Lanao del sur. She is 50 years old. Felipa is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Felipa owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Felipa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Felipa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Felipa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Felipa is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Felipa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Hawa A. is single and sells provisions at Abura. She has been through senior high school. She will use the loan to purchase more provisions to fill her shop for sale. She anticipates using the new profit that is going to accrue as a result of the loan to build her own house.

loans.use: purchase more provisions to fill her shop

loans.name: Agali Awamu Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: Christine is happily married and has 4 children. Self-interest was a driving force in establishing this modest hotel business in Lubugumu-Mukono. It has been in existence for 2 years now. She mostly sells local foods and all kinds of beverages. With weekly profits of 40,000 shillings, 43 year-old N. Christine, who belongs to Agali Awamu Development group, has supported herself and her family in various ways. To begin this business she had to bank on profits from a stone and sand quarry business, which she says was her first business. She still runs the quarry business, though her major priority is now overseeing the hotel. With this loan she wants to purchase more foods and beverages for her business.

loans.use: The purchase of more foods and beverages for her hotel.

loans.name: Enhbaatar

texts.en:
Enhbaatar N. is a 39 year old single man who lives with his mother, father and brother in Tuv province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His parents are both retired, while his brother works in the folksong and dance ensemble of Military as a singer. 

Enhbaatar uses a large van, or micro bus, to transport people within Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. He started driving in 1992. Since 2003, he has been transporting people by his micro-bus. He has found success with his business and has gained much experience as a driver over the years. His earnings have enabled him not only to improve his family's standard of living but also to purchase a new small car for his father. 

Enhbaatar is a very honest and hardworking person. For the future he hopes to continue to provide a quality and efficient transportation service. He is planning to purchase a new, good quality micro bus after selling his previous mini bus. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to upgrade his current mini bus.

loans.use: To upgrade his current mini bus.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce A. is currently in the business of selling sugar and rice and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice to sell. Joyce is 40 years old and is married to a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to stock crates of beer to sell.

loans.use: Stock more bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Gena

texts.en: Gena U. is from the village of Capayangan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 29 years old. Gena is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Gena runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Gena has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Gena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gena is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the third loan taken out by Gena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Mansueta

texts.en: Mansueta H. is from the village of Natappian West, Solana, Cagayan. She is 52 years old. Mansueta is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Mansueta sells a variety of vegetables in the local community. Mansueta has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Mansueta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mansueta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. Mansueta is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase a variety of vegetables to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Mansueta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina M. is married and smokes fish as well as frying them for sale at Abura. Amina serves her fish with 'Fante kenkey'. She has been educated up to the junior high level. Amina’s husband is a farmer. She will use the loan to buy more 'kenkey' and fry more fish for sale. She hopes to reinvest her profit back into her business.

loans.use: buy more 'kenkey' (fermented maize dough) and fry fish for sale

loans.name: Faith Kalagi Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Thirty-nine-year-old Sauda N. is affiliated with the Faith Kalagi Development Group. The group is based in Mukono. It has now been three years since she took root in her clothes-selling business. This married mother of six radiates a lively sense of humor and, above all, purposefulness. This has unquestionably been her mileage in the strides she has made over the years. Selling snacks was her first business preoccupation. 

In a week, her profits total up to 70,000 shillings. With this loan, Sauda wants to purchase more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: Purchase of more bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Bukasa Kirabo Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Thirty-six-year-old Joshua W. has deduced over time that it’s hard work that is the road to short- and long-term business success. These deductions are based on a decade-long experience that he says has helped him see the checkered nature of running a business. 

Joshua W., who belongs to the Bukasa Kirabo Group-Mukono, operates a brick-laying business. He is an easygoing married father of two children whose faces glow with excitement every time he sends them to school. It is a business he began with inspiration from a close friend. Prior to that, he was operating a retail shop. Joshua, who also plies a canteen business, says he makes 40,000 shillings a week. With this loan, he wants to buy more firewood for burning his bricks.

loans.use: The purchase of firewood for burning his bricks

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en: Marjorie Q. is from the village of Kabatangan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 27 years old. Marjorie is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Marjorie provides motorcycle (or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver for local community members. Marjorie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Marjorie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marjorie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Marjorie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed for maintenance to provide service. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Marjorie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed for maintenance to provide service

loans.name: Mamina

texts.fr:
Née le 03 Mai 1966 à Sikasso, Mamina B. est mariée et mère de 7 enfants dont 4 garçons et 3 filles  et réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Mancourani I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Mamina après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès,  s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et vente d’habillements (des bazins en couleurs, des pagnes wax, des  chaussures, des tissus brodés, etc.) depuis plus de dix ans. Elle achète  ses marchandises à Conakry (république de Guinée) avant de les revendre de façon ambulantes à une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes de ménage. 
Elle dispose aussi un frigo avec lequel elle mène la vente des glaces et des jus des fruits. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de six ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires  dans une association des femmes de leur quartiers dont elle était la présidente, elle est à son premier prêt individuel. Tous ses prêts solidaires précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Ce premier prêt individuel lui permettra d’acheter, 4 complets de bazin en couleur, 5 pièces de pagnes wax, 2 complets de tissus brodés et 5 paires de chaussures différentes.
 Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on 3rd May 1966 in Sikasso, Mamina B. is married and mother to seven children (four boys and three girls). She lives with her husband and their children in Mancourani 1, one of the working-class districts of the town of Sikasso (the Republic of Mali's third administrative region).

Having had many unsuccessful businesses, Mamina has been carrying out this business, buying and selling clothing (coloured damask fabric, "pagnes wax" - which are typical West African highly decorative and colourful pieces of fabric - shoes, embroidered material etc.) for more than ten years. She buys her supplies in Conakry (in the Republic of Guinea) before reselling them on a door-to-door basis, to a customer base made up essentially of housewives. She also has a fridge and uses this to sell ice-cream and fruit juice. She is in great demand from her customers for the quality of her products.  

In order to satisfy ever increasing customer demand, she decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, more than six years ago. Having had several group loans as part of a women's association in her neighborhood, of which she was president, she is now on her first individual loan. All the previous (group) loans were repaid in full. This first individual loan will allow her to buy four coloured damask fabric outfits, five pieces of "pagnes wax", two outfits in embroidered material and five pairs of different shoes.

With this loan, she is expecting to make a monthly profit of 90,000FCFA, which will be used essentially to increase her business, contribute to family expenses and pay the interest on her loan.

loans.use: To buy coloured damask fabric, "pagnes wax", shoes and embroidered material

loans.name: Erdenejargal

texts.en:
Erdenejargal C. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and 4-year-old son in her own "ger," a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her son attends a local kindergarten. 

Erdenejargal operates a key-duplicating service in a rented space with help of her husband. She started this business in 2009 after operating a grocery shop between 2006 and 2009. Her husband repairs house keys and doors on an on-call basis. 

She hopes to expand her business by upgrading her tools and equipment as well as to sell door hinges in addition to her key-duplication service. 

Erdenejargal is a modest and humble woman and says, “I want to continue operating this business with sustainable level so that I can establish my own shop in the future.” 

She is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan both to purchase a key-duplicating machine and to buy more raw materials that are used to make keys from Erlian, a border city of China.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials

loans.name: Zenabu

texts.en: Zenabu M. is a single parent who sells underwear by moving from one area to the other at Abura. She has been in this trade for a year now. She has been though senior high school. She will use the loan to buy more of her goods for sale. Zenabu plans on reinvesting the profit she hopes to get back into her business.

loans.use: buy more of her goods for sale

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity D. is currently in the business of selling maize, sorghum and cassava flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize and sorghum to sell.  

Charity is 40 years old and married to a NGO (non-governmental organization) staff member. She has seven children, six of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more bags of maize and sorghum to sell

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene P. is from the village of Natappian West, Solana, Cagayan. She is 57 years old. Arlene is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Arlene raises pigs for fattening and sale. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippines pesos (PHP) when she sells one of her raised pigs.

In 2008, Arlene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. 

Arlene is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other needed supplies. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Arlene from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other needed supplies

loans.name: Kugumikiriza Group-Jinja

texts.en:
O. Jane is a member of Kugumikiriza group-Jinja. She is widowed, has five children and for the last 10 years has principally been selling plastics and scrap metal as a means of earning a livelihood.  It’s a business she says is worthwhile as she does not have to incur any operational costs as she operates from home. 

Savings from a cassava selling business enabled her to jump-start this business. Jane says that what she has achieved in many respects boils down to two things - dedication and a sense of purpose. In the period of one week she says her profits equate to 130,000 shillings. With this loan, she is looking at buying more scrap that she says she will resell.

loans.use: To purchase more scrap to resell

loans.name: Sanata

texts.fr:
Madame   Sanata T. a plus de 27 ans, elle réside avec son époux et leurs  enfants (1garçon et 2 filles) à Wayerma II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame  Sanata T. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et vente des friperies il y a environ dix années. Elle mène son activité au grand marché de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis quinze années. Après 3 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.  
Après une pose, elle sollicite ainsi un troisième prêt lui permettant d’acheter, 3 balles de friperie de qualités différentes (T-Shirt, pantalons, chemises, napperons, serviettes, etc.). Elle achète ses marchandises sur place avec les grossistes avant de les revendre en détail.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sanata T. is over 27 years old. She lives with her husband and their children (a boy and two girls) in Wayerma II, a popular neighborhood of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

After attempting several activities without success, Mrs. T. started buying and selling used clothing about ten years ago. She works at the big market of Sikasso, where she is in high demand by her customers due to the quality of her merchandise.

To meet the needs of a steadily increasing customer base, she joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution 15 years ago. Having previously obtained three group loans as a member of a women’s association in her neighborhood, she eventually started applying for individual loans.

After a break, she is now seeking her third loan to buy three bales of used clothing (T-shirts, pants, shirts, placemats, napkins, etc.) of various grades. She buys her stocks on location from wholesalers, and then resells the merchandise at retail.

With this loan, she expects to make a monthly profit of 90,000FCFA,which will be used primarily to cover family expenses and pay the interest on the loan, with the remainder to be invested in her business.

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg B. is 47 years old and lives with her husband and 25-year-old daughter in Tuv province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her husband works as a driver for the local main hospital while her daughter is a doctor in the same hospital. 

Oyunchimeg operates a hair and beauty salon in her town along with four of her partners. They share the rent of a rented room to operate their salon named " Nahia Uschin". She has been working as a hairdresser since 1982 and has developed much experience. Her earnings have enabled her not only to provide for her family but also to pay her three children's tuition fees. She says, "I would like to open my own beauty and hair salon in the future." She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary supplies such as gel, foam, cream, hair color, etc. for her hair salon.

loans.use: To purchase necessary supplies

loans.name: Basekamajja Group-Mukono

texts.en:
N. Joy is a member of the BaseKamajja development group. For the past 15 years, she has been making ends meet selling agricultural produce like cassava, beans, rice and yams at a market stall in Kasambira-Jinja. She is a happily married mother with five children and she makes a weekly profit of 70,000 shillings. 

This business that started off small has enabled her to sustainably shoulder her responsibilities, be it the provision of her family's welfare or the growth of her business. Her first business was selling secondhand clothes. Her business, notwithstanding its success, has not grown at the pace that she envisioned. It’s for this reason that she is requesting this loan so she can purchase more agricultural produce in bulk to resell and hence to make more profit.

loans.use: To purchase more agricultural produce in bulk to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her stock of foodstuffs in the restaurant

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Florentina P. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 38 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Florentina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Florentina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Florentina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Florentina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. This will be the second loan that Florentina has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and provide working capital

loans.name: Boudrosse Al Maou

texts.fr:
Né le 02 Septembre 1983 à Kita (région de Kayes), Monsieur Boudrosse Al Maou K. est célibataire sans enfants résidant à Hamdallaye Extension, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
   Monsieur K., après avoir obtenu un certificat d’aptitude professionnelle en bâtiment (CAP BÂTIMENT),  s’est initié à la fabrique de savons qu’il a appris  à Bamako parallèlement  en marge de ses études il y a 6 ans. Il mène son activité à son domicile avant de les revendre à Koutiala et à San où il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a un année. 
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt il est à son deuxième prêt qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 4 fûts d’huile de coco, 3 sacs de soude caustique, 3 cartons de parfum différents, etc.
   Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on 2nd September 1983 in Kita (in the Kayes region), Mr. Boudrosse Al Maou K. is single, has no children, and lives in Hamdallaye Extension, one of the working-class districts of the town of Sikasso (the Republic of Mali's third administrative region).

Having obtained a professional building diploma, Mr. K. begain making soap, a business he learned in Bamako at the same time he was studying six years ago. He carries out his business at home and sells his soaps in Koutiala and in San, where he is in great demand from his customers due to the quality of his products. 

In order to satisfy his ever increasing customer base, he decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, a year ago. Having repaid his first loan in full he is on his second loan, which will be used to buy four barrels of coconut oil, three bags of caustic soda, three cartons of different perfumes, etc.

With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 200,000FCFA, which will be used primarily to expand his business, contribute to family expenses and pay interest on his loan.

loans.use: To buy basic materials for making soap

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny D. is from the village of Sto. Domingo, Echague, Isabela. She is 40 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jenny owns and operates a transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport in the local community. Jenny is just starting this business.

In 2009, Jenny joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. As with her previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which she has successfully repaid, this new loan of 10,000 PHP will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be the fourth loan that Jenny has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Haby

texts.fr:
Haby K. a plus de 53 ans est mariée et mère de 7 enfants (5garçons et 2 filles). Elle réside avec son époux, ses deux co-épouses et leurs enfants à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Haby K. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès notamment l’agriculture au village, elle s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et de vente de calebasses et divers depuis plus de dix ans. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ cinq ans. Après 6 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une Association des femmes de son quartier (Association BENKADI de Hamdallaye), elle est présentement à son troisième prêt individuel. Ses prêts précédents ont été  tous correctement remboursés. 
Ainsi, elle sollicite ce troisième prêt pour acheter, 10 colis de calebasses à Tona région de Ségou (quatrième région administrative du Mali) avant de les revendre  en détail au grand marché de Sikasso près de la mairie centrale de la localité à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes et surtout des miniers.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 170 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Haby K. is over 53 years old, married and mother to seven children (five boys and two girls). She lives with her husband, his two other wives and their children in Hamdallaye, one of the working-class districts of the town of Sikasso (the Republic of Mali's third administrative region).

Having had many unsucessful activities, notably village farming, she began her business buying and selling calabashes (fruit grown on a vine which can be dried and used as bottles or utensils) and other items more than ten years ago. 

In order to satisfy her ever increasing customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso's loan program about five years ago. After six group loans, as part of an association of women from her neighborhood (Hamdallaye's Benkadi Association) she is currently on her third individual loan. All her previous loans have been repaid in full. She is thus requesting a third loan to buy ten parcels of calabashes in the Tona area of Ségou (Mali's fourth administrative region) before reselling them on a retail basis at the large market in Ségou near to the town hall at the centre of the town, to a customer base made up mainly of women and above all miners. 

With this loan, she expects to make a monthly profit of 170,000FCFA, which will be used primarily to expand her business, contribute to family expenses and pay interest on his loan;

loans.use: To buy parcels of calabashes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock more food to sell

loans.name: Alinyikira Kazinga Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
B. Teo, aged 47, says she has mostly naively glossed over the things she does unwittingly that have led to groundbreaking improvements in her retail shop business in Kyaliwajjala-Mukono over the past 25 years. Having achieved that longevity, she says complacency may be playing a part. She, for example, has not often taken into account the fact that being cordial to clients is a 'stars and stripes' magic formula to lure more prospective or actual clients. 

This happily married mother of four exhilarating children says her good natured way of operating her business has got her more than she bargained for.  Teo who belongs to the Alinyikira Kazinga group-Mukono says her first business was selling charcoal and bananas. She makes 200,000 shillings in a month and with this loan she says she is going to purchase more retail items to resell. She says she is going to buy goods in bulk such as sugar, maize flour, soap, plastics, beans, rice, etc.

loans.use: To purchase more items e.g. sugar, maize flour, soap, etc. to resell

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita M. is from the village of Katutungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 56 years old, married and has eight adult children. To make a living, Estelita owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle or habal-habal services, with her husband as the driver, to local community members. Estelita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Estelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase materials needed to provide services. Estelita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed for vehicle maintenance in order to provide services. This will be the eighth loan that Estelita has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase necessary maintenance materials

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty J. is currently in the business of operating a small business selling clothes at the market. She is requesting a loan so she can stock more clothes to sell. Betty is 29 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has four children, three of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Né le 16 Juin 1976 à Sikasso, Monsieur  Adama B. est marié résidant avec son épouse et leurs trois enfants à Banconi, un des quartiers péripheriques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur B. après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au  domaine du petit commerce notamment  l’achat et la vente de volailles il y'a huit ans. Il dispose d’une place au niveau de marché de volailles de Wayerma I. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses volailles qui sont de bonnes qualités et bien suivis par des vétérinaires qualifiés. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il a bénéficié d’un premier crédit qui a été correctement remboursement. 
Ainsi, il sollicite ce deuxième crédit qui lui permettra d’acheter dans les villages environnants de la ville de Sikasso plus de volaille : 40 poulets, 18 pintades, 11 paires de dindons, 4 paires de canards, 3 paires d’oies etc. 
 Il envisage réaliser avec ce deuxième crédit, un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mr. Adama B. was born June 16, 1976 in Sikasso. He is married and lives with his wife and their three children in Banconi, a neighborhood on the outskirts of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

After attempting several activities without success, Mr. B. became involved in the business of buying and selling poultry eight years ago. He has a stall at the poultry market in Wayerma I. He is in high demand for the quality of his products, which consist of high grade poultry closely monitored by qualified veterinarians.

To satisfy a steadily growing customer base, he joined the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution and was granted his first loan, which he repaid in full.

He is now seeking a second loan to buy more poultry in the villages surrounding Sikasso: 40 chickens, 18 guinea fowls, turkeys 11 pairs of turkeys, 4 pairs of ducks, 3 pairs of geese, etc. 

With this loan, he expects to make an average monthly profit of 100 000FCFA, which will be used primarily to increase his working capital, cover family expenses and pay the interest on the loan.

loans.use: To buy poultry (chickens, guinea fowl, turkeys, etc.).

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia A. is from the village of Katutungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 48 years old. Virginia is married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, she sells daily use products such as lotion, soap and perfume in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Virginia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 8th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

texts.en:

To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $163 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Merlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.name: Djénèbou

texts.fr:
Djénèbou K. N. est une veuve de 37 ans et mère de cinq enfants dont 3 garçons et 2 filles qui vit avec ses enfants chez son défunt époux à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso.
Djénèbou K. N. mène cette activité d’achat et vente de  draps de lit,  de pagnes wax et  des chargements de bois de chauffe depuis plus de quatre  ans. 
Elle jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes, mais ses ressources ne peuvent pas lui permettre de les satisfaire. Ainsi, elle a besoin de ce  nouveau prêt individuel pour acheter, 10 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe et 10 paquets de draps, 2 complets de tissus brodés respectivement dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso et à Bobo Dioulaso (Burkina Faso) afin de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroitre.  
Elle est en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de trois ans  et  a  déjà bénéficié de plusieurs prêts solidaires avec une association des femmes de son quartier. Tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
  Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utiliser pour  contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djénèbou Koné N. is a 37 year old widow and mother of five children,3 boys and two girls, who lives with her children at her late husband’s home in Wayerma I, one of the lower-class neighbourhoods of the town of Sikasso.
Djénèbou Koné N. has been running her business of buying and selling bed linen, traditional fabric, and loads of firewood for over four years.
She has a good reputation in this field and receives numerous orders, but her resources are insufficient to enable her to satisfy the demand. Thus she needs this new individual loan to buy 10 cart loads of firewood, 10 packets of sheets, and 2 suits of fabric embroidered respectively in towns surrounding Sikasso and at Bobo Dioulaso (Burkina Faso) in order to satisfy her growing clientele.
She has been connected to Soro Yiriwaso for over three years and has already benefitted from several solidarity loans from a women’s association of her neighbourhood. All her loans have been repaid correctly.
With this loan she plans to make a monthly profit of 100 000 FCFA which will be used to contribute to family expenses, pay the interests of her loan and invest in her commerce.

loans.use: To purchase cart loads of firewood

loans.name: Akwata Empola Gayaza-Kampala Group

texts.en:
Her monthly cash income is estimated at close to $67 a month. With an experienced business resume spanning over three years, her confidence has sky rocketed despite the challenging nature of her medical clinic business with competition growing ever day. Despite this, her level of optimism has not plummeted at all. 

Meet 36-year-old N. Noah, a happily married woman with two children. Taking a long view of things is an attribute which has aided her a lot.  Norah belongs to Akwata empola group-Kampala. It was after listening to talk from close friends and family that she embarked on this business. With this loan she wants to purchase more drugs for her clinic.

loans.use: The purchase of more drugs for her clinic

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita S. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 55 years old. She is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she provides multicab (or habal-habal) services  to local community members, with her husband as the driver. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mercedita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. 

Mercedita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed for maintenance. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr:
Né le 16 décembre 1979 à Sikasso, Monsieur Ibrahima S. est un jeune célibataire vivant dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Médine-Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas eu la chance de progresser à l’école, il s’est vite initié à cette activité de coiffure des hommes et de vente d’articles divers depuis plus de six ans. Il jouit d’une forte réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes matériels de salon et divers, mais les ressources nécessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins fait défaut. 
Ainsi il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son troisième prêt, après des remboursements correctes des prêts précédents. 
Ce troisième prêt lui permettra d’acheter, 5 nouvelles tondeuses, 8 paires de peignes et brosses, 5 bidons d’eau de Javel, 5 bouteilles d’alcool à 90°, 5 cartons de déodorants, 15 cartons de savons Pharmapure, deux douzaines de parfums de différentes qualité, 1 carton de Timor, etc. Les marchandises sont achetées à Bamako (la capitale du Mali) avant de les revendre dans son salon situé au bord de la route RN7 avec une clientèle composée des jeunes mélomanes de la capitale du Kénédougou. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 230 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on the 16th December 1979 in Sikasso, Mr Ibrahima S. is a young bachelor living in a large, extended traditional family at Médine-Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali)
Not having had the good fortune to progress well in school, he rapidly devoted himself to the profession of hairdressing for men and the sale of various articles over six years ago. He has a very good reputation and receives numerous orders for salon equipment and various other products, but he does not have the funds to satisfy the demand.
This is why he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution with whom he is on his third loan, having correctly repaid the previous loans.
This third loan will enable him to purchase,5 new hair clippers,8 pairs of brushes and combs,5 cans of bleach,5 bottles of alcohol 90°,5 boxes of deodorants,15 boxes of Phamapure soap, two dozen different quality perfumes ,1 box of  Timor,etc. The merchandise is bought at Bamako (the capital of Mali) and resold in his salon that is situated on the side of the RN7 road to a clientele of young music lovers from the capital of Kénédougou.
With this loan, he hopes to make  a net monthly profit of  230 000 FCFA.With the profits made ,he plans  to settle  most of his expenses, and those of his family ,pay the interests of his loan and invest the remainder in his business.

loans.use: To purchase various articles .

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en: Kiden B. is currently in the business of selling sugar, rice and cooking oil in her shop and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and cooking oil to sell. Kiden is 28 years old and is single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more bags of sugar and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Anara

texts.en:
Anara B. is 39 years old. She has three children: two sons, the elder of which is serving in the army, and one daughter of school age. Her husband works as an electrician at the state power plant. In 2005, in order to support her family, Anara began her business of selling lingerie with the initial capital of 15,000 KGS. She worked hard and managed to expand the range of goods and raise her floating capital. With the revenues, she was able to pay for education for her second son. 

Anara will use this loan of 52,000 KGS to broaden the range of products she sells. With the revenues, she plans to give a good education to her daughter. Anara dreams of buying a car for her family in the future. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase goods for reselling

loans.name: Bobomurot

texts.ru: Халлиев Бобомурот проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 50 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Дети работают в дехканском хозяйстве. Сам Бобомурот имеет среднее образование. Более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Bobomurot H. lives in the Shahrituz district.  He is 50 years old, married and has 3 children.  His wife is a homemaker.  His children work at a dekhan farm.  Bobomurot has a secondary education.  He has been involved in agriculture for over 10 years.  He has a plot of land at home, where he grows vegetables.  Bobomurot is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Herminia

texts.en:
Herminia P. is from the village of Francfort, Bumbaran, Lanao del Sur. She is 39 years old. Herminia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products, and also retailing rice per kilogram in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $225 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Herminia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Herminia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 7th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella T. is currently in the business of selling clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell.  She is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has two children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her clothing sales business.

loans.use: Stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Hanna Jean

texts.en:
Hanna Jean V. is from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 22 years old. Hanna Jean is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Hanna Jean owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. In 2010, Hanna Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hanna Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Hanna Jean is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed for the maintenance to provide service. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Hanna Jean from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed for the maintenance of their motorcycle transport business

loans.name: Mpasha Bamwe A, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hard working and determined T. Angella, aged 35 years, has a dependable sense of purpose regarding anything to do with her 8 yearold agro produce business. She has worked tirelessly to keep her business that trades in bananas sales, maize and other food crops from Mpasha trading centre, Ibanda. On the sunny side her strong work ethic has gotten her far as her business currently generates 120,000 Ugandan shillings on Monthly basis. 

The married mother of 2 children began her business when she bought land for agricultural use using the money she had borrowed from a village bank and other savings from her previous coffee selling business. With this loan she looks forward to buying fertilizers for her plantations so that she will be able to get more produce for sell. This will increase her sales revenue and enable her to meet her family expenses.

loans.use: purchase of fertilizers for the plantation

loans.name: Togoontumur

texts.en:
Togoontumur S. is 45 years old and lives with her husband and two adult aged sons in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son attends university while her youngest and her husband both help out with Togoontumur's business. 

She has operated a dairy product retail business in her town at the local market since 1995. She sells a fermented milk in the summer months, and during the fall and winter months she sells a variety of dairy products. After many years of successful operation, she has not only gained much experience but also a wide range of customers. 

Her earnings have enabled her to pay her sons' tuition fees. Togoontumur is a very open minded and hardworking woman, she says, " I am very glad that my business has helped me to improve greatly our family's standard of living" She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more dairy products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products

loans.name: Twendagane Development Group-Jinja

texts.en:
K. Susan is 24 years old and she belongs to Twendagane Development Group-Jinja. Though she has been inundated with the stereotypical view that women’s chances of success in business are low, she like other entrepreneurial women has chosen to blaze a trail that will go a long way in demystifying that idea. It is 3 years ago that she drew up the blueprint that started her beauty salon, home decoration and poultry businesses in Bugembe-Jinja. She accords credit to her mom whom she says inspired her. 

Previously she was working in a local factory. 350,000 shillings is what accrues to her business weekly. Susan is married with 2 kids. With this loan, she wants to buy more chicks for her poultry business.

loans.use: The purchase of more chicks for her poultry business

loans.name: Marianita

texts.en:
Marianita G. is from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 54 years old. Marianita is married and has 10 adult-aged children. To make a living, Marianita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Marianita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marianita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marianita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marianita is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marianita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en: Altantsetseg D., 57, lives in the Chingeltey district of Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. She and her family all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter, who has a one-year-old son, has recently graduated from Mongoljingoo University, majoring in design. She helps out with her mother's business. Altantsetseg operates a small sewing business in her home. She produces a variety of clothing items according to her customers' orders. She started her sewing business in 1999 after working as a tailor and master in a sewing company since 1970. For the future, Altantsetseg hopes to improve her business. She is requesting a 500000 MNT loan to purchase a new sewing machine as well as more fabrics and materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence N., 35 years old, has been selling second-hand clothes for the last seven years in Central Market-Jinja. This is a business she began with financial support from her husband. Even with no experience, this mother of two still made progress. In a month she makes 300000 shillings. She also has a rental business that brings additional profits. She describes herself as hard-working and amiable. With this loan she wants to buy more bales of clothes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase bales of clothing for resale

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene M. is from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 37 years old. Arlene is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene raises livestock for sale, primarily chickens. Arlene has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Arlene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the second loan taken by Arlene from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Bulgantamir

texts.en: Bulgantamir B. is a 26-year-old married man with one infant son. He lives with his wife and son in Arhangai province in central Mongolia in their ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Bulgantamir operates a dairy products and meat-trading business in his town with the help of his wife. He started both businesses five years ago with working capital of 1000000 MNT and has built a stable operation over the years. He usually purchases his dairy and meat products from herders in the countryside and sells them in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. Today, his working capital exceeds 2300000 MNT and his earnings have enabled him to provide for his family. For the future, Bulgantamir hopes to expand his businesses and to buy his own apartment for his family in Ulaanbaatar. Bulgantamir is an open-minded and hard-working man. He is requesting a 2000000 MNT loan to purchase more dairy products as well as meats for his businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products and meat

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia A. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 55 years old. Alicia is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Alicia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling food and daily use products in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for more than ten years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Alicia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be Alicia's fifth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase of a water tank and more spare parts for resale

loans.name: Delgertsogt

texts.en:
Delgertsogt E., 28, lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Tuv Province, Mongolia. His oldest daughter, age 7, attends local primary school, while his youngest son, age 4, is in kindergarten. Delgertsogt and his wife own a second-hand raw material trading business in their town, buying raw materials locally and selling the materials in the reprocessing factories for a profit. In addition, he is a welder and makes a variety of steel/iron doors according to customers' orders to supplement his earnings.

With his earnings, Delgertsogt has been able to start building a house. He would like to one day own his own supermarket where he could sell a variety of consumer goods and grocery products. A modest, honest and hardworking man, Delgertsogt is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to increase his working capital and build a new house that will used as a service center.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita M. is from the village of Tumbao, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 52 years old,  married, and has nine adult children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase of building materials

loans.name: Ganhuyag

texts.en:
Ganhuyag S. is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Huvsgul Province of Mongolia. Both of daughters, ages 12 and 16, attend local school, while Ganhuyag operates a transportation business in his town that he began in 2009 and has built into a stable operation. In addition, he purchases meats at wholesale prices which he resells at the Murun sub province for a profit.

A very active and business-minded man, in order to increase his earnings Ganhuyag plans to buy a bigger van that can carry more people. He is therefore requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan for the purchase.

loans.use: To buy a new van

loans.name: Tsogtbayar

texts.en:
Tsogtbayar P. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in Tuv province in central Mongolia. He lives together with his family in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His two elder sons, ages 14 and 12, both attend local secondary school while his youngest son, age 4, is in kindergarten. His wife works as a private businesswoman, and Tsogtbayar manages a traditional Mongolian shoe-making business in his town with help of his wife. He makes a variety of Mongolian shoes that Mongolians have worn since ancient times. 

Tsogtbayar started his business in 2002 and has built up a stable and successful operation. His earnings have enabled him not only to provide for his family but also to buy his own house and fence. For the future, he hopes to have his own shoe production factory. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase, at wholesale prices, more fabrics and materials used in making his traditional shoes.

loans.use: To purchase more fabrics and materials

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with three children all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are electricity bills and school fees for her children.  

For over fifteen years she has operated her retail shop selling sugar, tea leaves, and maize flour. Asha's potential customers are her neighbours and passersby. She faces the major challenge of competition as many retail shops sell similar products. She hopes to buy a plot of land in the future to construct rental houses.

Her major reason for working with Yehu is its good reputation. With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase ten bags of charcoal, five bags of beans and maize for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase ten bags of charcoal, five bags of beans and maize for her shop

loans.name: Ma'zum

texts.ru: Мамашарипов Маъзум проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 39 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Более 6 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Арендует торговую точку, где продает продукты питания. В этом ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара. На полученную прибыль клиент хочет отремонтировать дом.
texts.en: Ma'zum M. lives in the Shahrituz district.  He is 39 years old, married and has 3 children.  He has a secondary education.  He has been involved in retail sales for over 6 years.  Ma'zum leases a retail outlet, where he sells food products.  His wife helps him with this business.  He is requesting this loan in order to expand merchandise variety.  The client wants to use the resulting profit to repair his house.

loans.use: Expanding merchandise variety

loans.name: Hoji

texts.en:
Hoji is married with four children. He owns a small business selling various construction materials and household goods. Hoji has been in this business for 11 years. Hoji's little store is located in the central market. The good location and good prices bring in many customers.

 Hoji is a very responsible and disciplined person. He has used business loans before and always paid them back on time. This time, Hoji is requesting a loan of 12,000 Somoni to purchase additional inventory. He hopes to increase sales and to develop his business further. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing construction materials and household goods

loans.name: Asadu

texts.en:
25-year-old M. Asadu has been in his commercial motorcycle business in Bwaise-Kampala for one and a half years now. By and large, his circumstances have been a mixture of good and bad. Bad given the increasing competition that directly translates to frustration, especially on days when clients are few. Good on the basis that at least he is able to make ends meet. Often he has had to begin with a new slate after some disappointing days at work. 

Upbeat tenacity, courage and perseverance stand out as his winning attributes. 50,000 shillings as weekly profits is quite modest but he remains optimistic that with this loan he can make a lot of headway in his trade. At his young age Asadu is already married with four high-spirited kids. 

 Asadu looks back with nostalgia at the time when he was a builder.  It is with money saved from building houses that he was able to purchase his motorcycle. With this Kiva loan, he says he is going to buy another motorcycle that he says will go a long way toward enabling him to earn more profit.

loans.use: The purchase of another motorcycle

loans.name: Thekrayat

texts.en:
Thekrayat is a young woman from Jenin city. Her father and one of her brothers are Palestinian National authority employees.

Thekrayat is a university student and works in a women's wear store. Her family needed to enlarge their house, and since they own the land where the house is constructed, they started building an extension. The family together is contributing to cover the expenses, so Thekrayat came to FATEN and took a $1,500 loan which is the amount they need to cover the last expenses.

Thekrayat's brother appears in the picture here as she is not comfortable with having her picture published.

loans.use: Building a house extension

loans.name: Inoyat

texts.en:
Inoyat is married. She is an entrepreneur from Istaravshan city, where she runs a small clothing sales business. Inoyat sells kid’s clothing items in one of the local markets. She is an experienced market vendor, and has been running this venture for 6 years. Inoyat recognizes a good opportunity to broaden the selection of goods she offers and increase her sales volume. She is requesting a loan of 7500 Somoni to increase the selection of clothing merchandise she offers for sale. 

Inoyat is known as an open and lively woman who cares about her customers' needs. As she provides for the needs of others, she will be able to generate the necessary funds to adequately provide for herself and her family.

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.use: Purchasing new goods to sell

loans.name: Mutahira

texts.en: Mutahira is married and has three children. She sells kids' clothing at the market of Istaravshan. Mutahira started this business 10 years ago because her family was in need. She began selling clothing and really liked it. Eventually, she was able to rent some space at the market. Since that time her business has been even better. Today it is a stable additional source of income for her growing family. Mutahira would like to borrow 7,500 Somoni to increase the assortment of her inventory. She hopes to increase her sales and to receive additional income. loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing the new clothing in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Improve the store

loans.name: Abbos

texts.en:
Abbos is married with two children. Their family lives in Isfara, Tajikistan. Abbos owns a small enterprise selling dried fruits like dried apricot, raisins, pistachios etc. in the local market. His business is well known in the marketplace for reasonable and affordable prices and so attracts many customers. Abbos has been in the trade for 10 years and has learned a lot about making his business a profitable one.

He is requesting a loan of $1000 USD to increase his turnover capital. With this, he intends to generate additional income to be set aside for the education of his children, who will soon need to start thinking about college. As Abbos is an experienced businessman and a responsible father, we believe the current loan will benefit his small venture and assist his family.
